description.narrative:
What social dynamics are at play in Ebola transmission - and how can we mediate biomedical risk? Existing Ebola action plans place little emphasis on these questions. This project will seek to address the issues with a workshop and recommendations.
Beyond Ebola's biomedical impact The international community has mostly focused its attention on the disease as a biomedical problem. Little has been done to account for socio-economic, political, or cultural determinants and impacts of the disease. Yet they may have enormous effects on behaviours that will affect transmission rates and fatalities.
Evaluating approaches, offering guidance The workshop aims to review and assess current measures and approaches to the Ebola outbreak. It will serve to create the American Anthropological Association's Advisory Task Force on the Ebola Outbreak Emergency. The group will include 25 to 30 anthropologists with research expertise in Guinea, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Nigeria, and other threatened nations in the region. It will also include anthropologists whose research has focused on the social dynamics of infectious disease and epidemics, or the humanitarian response. Some Canadian and American experts will participate.
The workshop is expected to result in actionable recommendations that will help professionals in the field to improve their technical, political, social, and economic management efforts to contain the crisis. It will also identify important knowledge and awareness gaps that are likely to influence the effectiveness of international efforts to respond to the crisis.
The two-day workshop takes place Nov 6?7, 2014 at George Washington University in Washington, DC.
Examining Ebola's long-term outlook The group will recommend immediate actions to alleviate the severity of the crisis. They will also begin to assess the longer-term outlook and potential response efforts in a context in which public health, governance, and human security conditions were already tenuous before the outbreak.
They will highlight the need to address the structural conditions that have facilitated the crisis, constrained response to it, and will likely deteriorate further because of it. Areas for immediate intervention and longer-term consideration include: -health systems strengthening -public health promotion -epidemic tracking and intervention -violence, security, and governance -food security, livelihoods, and socio-economic vulnerability -stabilization
